(44) 6-54,lQth November, 1944.WAR CABINET.CIVIL AIR TRANSPORT: CHICAGO CONFERENCE.Memorandum by the Lord Privy Seal.THE Special Committee on Civil Air Transport unanimously recommends that, subject to a satisfactory reply from the Colonies concerned, who have been consulted, authority be given to Lord Swinton to negotiate a satisfactoryExecutive Agreement at Chicago with the following terms : (a) National Quotas to be allocated on the basis of '' traffic embarked '' anda 60 per cent, load factor.(&) During an Interim Period of three years from the end of the War withGermany, "War " Nations to be free to take up their national quotasat any time, without prejudice,(c) A Fifth Freedom to be conceded by all Great Powers, providing the rightto pick up and set down traffic between two foreign territories.2. Concession of the Fifth Freedom would be subject to the followingsafeguards: (a) It would apply only to through services.(b) Fares for intermediate journeys on through services must be higher thanthose on parallel local services.(c) Such fares and other conditions to be determined and enforced by inter-national machinery.(d) There should be a trial period of three years after which the ExecutiveAgreement could be revoked at six months' notice.3. The Special Committee asks the War Cabinet to authorise acceptanceof an Executive Agreement on these principles subject to assurance that it wouldbe adhered to by all Nations in the same way as a Multilateral Convention.B.Gwydyr House, S.W. 1,16th November, 1944.([28626]
